alternative_title: Employers' tax and reporting for parking spaces
overview: Tax and reporting rules for employers providing parking spaces
title: Expenses and benefits: parking spaces

table.body:
As an employer providing parking spaces for your employees, you have certain National Insurance and reporting obligations.

##What's included

This covers parking spaces for vehicles including cars, motorcycles and bicycles.

These spaces may be at or near your employee’s workplace, or spaces used while on a 'business journey'.

A business journey is either:

* part of your employees duties, eg a service engineer travelling to an appointment
* a journey your employee has to make to get to a temporary workplace

^There are different rules if you [cover the costs of employees' parking](/expenses-and-benefits-car-parking-charges "cover the costs of employees' parking"), rather than providing parking spaces yourself.^
table.title: Overview

table.body:
You don’t have to report or pay anything to HMRC if you:

* provide parking spaces at or near your employee’s workplace
* provide any parking spaces to employees who earn [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of less than £8,500 a year

^You don't have to pay tax or National Insurance on parking spaces provided for business journeys, but you may still have to [report these expenses](/expenses-and-benefits-parking-spaces/what-to-report-and-pay "report these expenses") to HMRC.^

*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: What's exempt

table.body:
If the parking spaces you provide aren’t [exempt](/expenses-and-benefits-parking-spaces "exempt"), you may have to report them to HMRC, and you may have to pay National Insurance on the cost.

##Spaces you provide for use on business journeys

If you provide parking spaces for business journeys, you can [apply for a dispensation](/apply-for-a-dispensation "apply for a dispensation"), which means you won’t have to include them on your end-of-year reports.

If you don't have a dispensation, and you provide these spaces for employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of £8,500 or more a year, or directors, you’ll need to report them on form P11D, section K, L or N.

You don't have to pay tax or National Insurance on these parking spaces.

##Other parking spaces you provide

This covers parking spaces you provide that aren't either:

* at or near the employee's workplace
* for use on a business journey

If you provide these spaces for employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of £8,500 or more a year, or directors, you'll need to:

* report on form P11D, section K, L or M
* pay Class 1A National Insurance on the cost to you of providing the parking space

*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
